review_title: Very smart people, good organization, but room to improve
job_title: Executive Director in New York, NY
pros: Very smart people.  High performing environment.  You are challenged in your work.  Relatively good balance with personal life if needed, especially for family issues or emergencies.  Opportunities for creativity and innovation are rewarded.
cons: Very difficult to take the next step in your career.  Organization remains very siloed so hard to move to different areas and find new opportunities.  Easy to stall out.  Pay is nowhere near as good as competitors at this time.  Easily 20-40% under market.

review_title: Not at all what I was sold on!
pros: Paid Studying, potentially good name on your resume, pretty flexible time wise depending on your location, good benefits, Potential to learn a lot
cons: Mgmt has no follow through, a lot of empty promises.  if you aren't a self starter and can't bring money in immediately don't start at MSSB.  The training program is a joke, you will be lucky to sit down with your manager at all during training, very unorganized, sink or swim mentality.  Office dynamics can be very uncohesive, don't expect to hang out with people from work. don't expect any product training, and be okay with finding clients and then learning the job.

review_title: Low morale in some sales and trading divisions is hurting business
pros: Decent pay, good hours if in sales and trading, smart people, relatively stimulating work
cons: Plenty of office politics and unpleasant work environment, especially given recent uncertainty regarding the future of certain divisions. Excessive regulation makes it tough to do business, so volumes/pay much lower than five years ago. Low internal mobility unless one has a powerful mentor. Double standards abound, i.e. firm sponsorship of MBA programs no longer exists officially, yet some individuals receive sponsorship nevertheless. While this is not true of all divisions, the old Wall Street boys' club mentality is alive and well in some areas, which makes it tough to thrive, or even last, as a woman.

review_title: Great firm to start your career at
job_title: Analyst – Origination in New York, NY
pros: It's very gratifying to work with smart colleagues on significant and interesting deals. In many front office roles, Morgan Stanley attempts to differentiate itself from competition by providing complex and tailored product offerings  – it's more interesting work. The firm has a strong reputation and employees learn transferrable skills Mobility within the firm is also excellent.
cons: For many junior employees (tends to be true across finance), there is a dearth of advancement opportunities within the firm. Motivated individuals often need to find a next job outside of MS within 1-3 years of initially joining, which can be tricky if working long hours.

review_title: Great Company, just a few but's
pros: Great team culture. Learn a lot of different aspect of equity market. The company is so deep in many areas. Say you need IT support in a python package or you need to setup approval system for some resources, you can expert help after writing a few emails.
cons: As you climb the ladder, there are a lot of politics. I feel higher up sometime value loyalty way over abilities. Another thing is that there is waste in the company, sometime i see consultants are hire for not very good reason.

pros:
Some folks joining from Indian IT majors like Infy, TCS, wipro may find salary lucrative.  
If you are laid-off, you may get few months of salary as severance pay.
cons:
Wealth Management Technology division seems to be too confused.  They hired an MD few years back and made him leave within 2.5 years because he was trying to bring power to Mumbai office and trying to create true leaders. On the US side, another MD was hired who was also made to leave within 2 years. Then, another MD was brought in his place who resigned within 1 year and then took his resignation back within a month. But resigned again after 1 year.

The folks at Executive Director level (which is equivalent to a Manager role in other IT companies) seriously lack team leading skills. But  they are not to be blamed because they just adapted themselves to overall company culture. 
Strangely, Management's ideology is to maintain an insecure environment because they feel that is the only way people will perform to their potential.  Do not ever raise concerns unless you have another job offer because you will be next in line in the firing range.
Layoffs are very common irrespective of company's performance.  Mumbai office management is still struggling to create a positive culture even after so many years. Senior management recently did a brainstorming and came to the conclusion that reason for bad company culture is the employees hired from Indian IT services companies and they feel folks from other Investment banks are better fit for their culture as they already have the habit of being a slave. So, they have now started to target those employees for layoffs. Very intelligent management, I must say.

review_title: I worked as a financial advisor associate. Base is $55k that goes down towards end of 3 year program.  Lots of upside.
job_title: Financial Advisor Associate in New York, NY
pros: Plenty of opportunities to increase compensation. You have the freedom to work whichever, wherever and wherever you want. Lots of resources at the firm to assist in meeting goals.
cons: Challenging career path nowadays. Price compression and increased regulatory oversight allows for less compensation in some regards. Competition is Fierce.

pros: on of the highest salaries, working with people across multiple branches (US, Canada, London etc.), nice company events, ok fringe benefits
cons: everyone has their own assignment independenlty, no testers, developer have the sole responsibility from start to finish, having to realase to prod in the middle of the night, boring tasks with always changing requiremnets, horrible code quality, boring / legacy technologies, lots of stress, few open source technologies - lots of in house ones, terrible work-life balance, overtime not compensated properly, old timey strict hierarchy, very few people get pomoted thus having a career path

pros: Unlimited earnings potential and best in class offerings
cons: Chance of starting a practice here are very slim.   Most people who successfully complete the training program are brought into an existing team and fed business.  Most other trainees are just a way for experienced brokers to be fed business after they fail out.  You are given no direction and are just a number on your managers spreadsheet.  Production hurdles if you finish the training program are unrealistic and pay drops as low as 20% if you don't hit production goals.

job_title: On Behalf of All Junior Designations in Bangalore
pros:
1) Free cab service and special attention to women safety
2) 1-month paternity leave
3) You'll remain in your own country (No on-site opportunities)
4) Average recreational room with 2 Foosball tables, 2 TT tables
cons:
1) Too many budget conversations
2) Not at all employee friendly (ex. No budget for team outings/events, No benefits related to tax savings, poor cafeteria, no auditorium, etc...)
3) Late night calls to sync up with US folks
4) Heavily dependent on legacy systems
5) Bonus is not at all related to one's performance

pros: You meet and work with talented and unique co-workers.  There are opportunities to work and live in various departments and cities.  If the idea of living and working abroad on million dollar projects with some of the smartest people you will ever meet sounds enticing then this is the place for you.
cons: Long hours and a lot of your compensation comes down to the end of year bonus.  You are compensated very handsomely, but it comes at the cost of working a ton of hours.  It is hard to complain when your boss is putting in 80 hours per week.

review_title: Poor work life balance, employees treated like commodities
pros: Office is in New York
cons:
I was only at MS for a brief period, but when I was there, I worked very long hours. They have very little appreciation or recognition for hard work.  Appreciation is not reflected in compensation or in how they treat you.  

Getting promoted is definitely like running for political office.  You have to know some people at the top (and widespread) to get promotions.  I was hired one level below when I joined, promised a promotion opportunity during that year by the head of my group as part of my negotiation.  Upon joining MS, I was quickly told that information was untrue, but was tempted with that carrot again when I gave my notice.  Everyone is out for themselves, don't trust anyone at Morgan.

job_title: Manager in Kowloon City, Kowloon City
pros: Smart and good people.  Many are very impressive and one can learn a lot from them.  Work environment is generally good.
cons: Very political environment.  Personal progress is very dependent on who you know and their position more so than what you know and do.  Pace of work forces managers to let staff work on their own which is good, but pace of work also means managers cannot focus on assessing performance so staff have to become political to get recognition.

pros: Working on my team provides a great work life balance. I work with a great group of people in the office - I haven't worked with a group like this anywhere else! The experience is amazing, you have to learn fast,but if you keep up you'll find yourself never bored and learning something new every day.
cons: As an Assistant with a Masters Degree, the pay is incredibly poor. FAs get paid well if they're successful, but CSAs are paid by the firm, and in my experience its not as much as they're worth. I do believe it is somewhat comparable to other firms in the industry. Working in a small area as compared to a big city limits opportunities for advancement and learning.

review_title: Great technology infrastructure, smart people, not too close to the 'business'
pros:
- MS has got a great and consistent technology infrastructure. As an example it is very common that a new joiner gets access to all systems and is able to be productive on the first day
- It varies from team to team but there are many smart people, including managers. The grad programme is very good. I haven't done it myself but I've worked with many grads and it's generally a very good experience.
cons: - In my team I didn't have much exposure to the 'business' - we didn't sit with the traders, we had separate social events and I really could feel like I was an inferior employee, physically separated from the 'important' guys

review_title: Good company, outsoucing is killing it
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Compnay generally has talented employees, very good enterprise infrastructure and resource, which is very helpful for IT team.  Cutting edge technology, many in house trainning available, both online and in person.
cons: Management push to offshore outsourcing has greatly reduce quality of support to zip for both IT and business.  New York employee felt marginalized, and moral is low.

pros:
There is so much politics in the backoffice groups and all groups for that matter. 

My advice, take copious notes from day 1. That way people will be careful with playing games with you. Write down who said what/when/why and ALWAYS ask people for due dates on assignments. Keep a calendar of assignments and first estimate how long it will take you to do an assignment before you commit to a time. 

Manage your time and don't let people take advantage of you.
cons:
People don't like to see ambitious people succeed and you have to wait atleast 2 years to move internally. 

Seek out training the street internally and use the 10k for tuition reimbursment! Make sure to use ALL company resources.

pros: wealth management business is growing, excellent access to market research and insights, on-going Tech training, opportunity to learn about all facets of the business, treat clients as top priority, great service to customers
cons: management is not actively involved in making sure it is a workplace of respect and integrity. the firm always does the right thing for the client but not always for its own employees. certain advisers are very disrespectful and management does nothing to change it because the advisers are tied to revenue

review_title: Not the place to be for a Software Developer
pros: Good brand name for the CV (Not sure if it is the same in the near future)
cons:
* Increasingly low compensation. All about cost cutting these days.
* Not all but many people in the firm put emphasis on self importance. 
* Some managers have anger issue and like to humiliate/criticize others publicly.
* Bonus, promotion, and compensation is not based on performance but more focused on visibility and networking with management. 
* Although the bonus is meant for last years performance, if they think you will leave soon, they give you nothing.
* Deprecated technology / Morgan Stanley in-house developed technologies are used in the project (Re-inventing the wheel but in a worse way).
* Talented people are leaving resulting in degrading quality of software development and architecture.
* Graduate program no longer sends people to NY (as part of cost saving).

review_title: Smart People, Deep Relationships, Needs get its Swagger Back
pros: over 22 years, I had the opportunity to shape my career and life many times working with empathic, sharp colleagues.  I didn't need to leave to transform career. Built amazing working relationship through many highs and lows.  Many long tenured leaders and culture carriers.
cons: Politics and Silos have to be carefully navigated at many senior levels.   You can recognise the waves of senior recruits from other banks as they attempt to change the culture like oil and water.

pros: Ok if you're interested in integration responsibilities related to the merger.  Friendly co-workers and mangers.  Once the firm figures out its direction and is ready to put money and effort behind it, morale could turn around.
cons: Senior managers don't care about employees, only the bottom line.  Potentially long commutes lead to negative work-life balance.  Hard-workers are only rewarded with more work, not more money or respect.

pros:
- Great autonomy
- Good funding for marketing events
- Location great
- Platform top notch
- Fair compensation
- Great leadership
- a lot more..
cons:
- Not a lot of support until you do $150K GDC
- Cold Caling
- Poor success rate of new advisors
- Extreme barriers to entry for new advisors in the industry

pros:
Top people, systems, processes in the industry.
Promoted autonomous working (but occasionally, just left you to it a little too much)
Great almost family/team atmosphere
All the good things about Goldman's but a little more relaxed and not as pressured
cons:
Heavy work load due to a very lean environment (MS prefer fewer but meaner employees rather than lots of mediocre staff)
True ownership/entrepreneurial spirit - directed from the top.
Employees have to wear a lot of "hats".  Management try too hard to get employees to rotate but don't necessarily relinquish their previous responsibilities so they take on far too much.

review_title: A retail brokerage, not an investment bank anymore
pros: Morgan Stanley's IT department focuses on some aspects of work-life balance well, like support for certifications and working from home.
cons: Compensation has been on a pretty steady trend downwards - double-digit percent cuts are not made up by the occasional "better" year that goes up maybe 2%. Opportunities for career growth have always been limited by a highly competitive environment that has gotten more competitive as management has chosen to flatten the org by letting go of people with more senior titles.

review_title: Firm tends to get rid of employees of a certain age and/or salary in order to control costs.
pros: Most employees are nice people. Decent work / life balance for the most part. Good benefits. People seem to genuinely care about the client.
cons: Entire divisions are eliminated and replaced by employees 20 years younger (or consultants). Salaries are below what are paid in other firms. The term 'Morgan Stanley Poor' is a common phrase. Many senior executives don't have advanced degrees & it shows.

job_title: IT Services Lead in Atlanta, GA
pros: MS was a good place to work, as I had a boss that was out of state, and was pretty hands off.  The salary and benefits were nice.  Great people, diverse workforce.
cons: Salary, when compared to hours work per week would have been about $5 per hour.  Included weekends, and there was little recognition at the end of the year for those hours spent.

job_title: Financial Advisor Associate in Montgomery, AL
pros: Great people that takes care of you, leadership really cares about your success and will do what they can to get you there
cons: Numbers are high but they are looking for young people and a lot of the older people who have been in the business may seem to feel that they are better than you or they don't want anything to do with you.

pros:
Lured by good package while joining
Leave policies
cons:
Yearly firing based on eliminating redundancy.
Proclaims itself to use cutting edge/latest technology.
Most of the projects still live in the stone age era. 

College Grads who join here are treated as babies. They will be given preference over lateral hires throughout their career. You could find a 5-10 years experience lateral guys being lead by a 2-3 years Grad, who have no industry experience what so ever. 1 Year Grad is equivalent to 5 years Lateral hires.
Lateral hires will take 3-5 years to get a promotion which a grad will get in 1 year. Firm speaks so much about equal opportunity, but I don't understand how it is encouraged in this case.

Too much politics and favoritism. You need to have higher level contacts to survive.

Not a place for people who are technically strong.

review_title: Great overall culture, but teams can be outliers
job_title: Full Stack Developer in Glasgow, Scotland
pros:
- Great collaborative culture between teams. You can reach out to pretty much anyone in any Morgan Stanley office and they will usually happily oblige. 
- Mobility between teams is often facilitated
cons: - Lack of anonymous feedback opportunities for contingent workers. I was the only full time worker in a team of other contingents in Glasgow, who had no recourse to yearly anonymous feedback for their managers, like full time workers too. This resulted in their grievances not being addressed for quite a long period of time, especially given that the contingent workers did not know other senior people in the team (all of whom were located outside of Glasgow) whom they could reach out to.

job_title: Associate Financial Advisor in Tacoma, WA
pros: Morgan Stanley has a great brand and some of the best intellectual capital in the world.  Strong senior management and good communication with the employees for the most part. Very strong investment banking, Prime Brokerage and fixed income departments.
cons: They are very behind on technology and training.  Goals and requirements are very tough for new advisors.  Turnover is very high.  The biggest producers are taken care of the smaller a producer you are the less management watches out for you.

review_title: It's a good experience to see how an office operates and I'm learning a lot.
pros: The people there are extremely friendly. I love the work environment and I would absolutely love to work at a place like this after I graduate. You can work at a fairly relaxed pace.
cons:
Early hours... but good if you're a morning person! 
Sometimes it gets slow as an intern. There are occasions where my boss is not available to speak to since he is talking to clients, so I spend some time sitting around and waiting for him to finish.

job_title: Senior Technologist in New York, NY
pros:
Management has open door policy
Fair compensation, although closely tied to market performance
You get an opportunity to present your ideas
Most position offer a balance between work and personal life
cons:
Too much reliance on off shore
Very strong silo structure, typical for large companies
Minimal information sharing across teams
Often need a push from senior managers to get others to committ
Need to improve overall competency of technology staff

review_title: Beware of bureaucracy and follow Lord Krishna's advice and don't expect rewards ....
pros:
You really need to work hard to get where you want to. There are some smart and dynamic people you will meet along the way -- but man, don't expect them to reward you on time. The word, "on time" is key here. Promotions are important to retain talent and motivate employees. MS fails to understand that.
Designations are important for any employee but you are always told by the senior management that "it is a multi year process to get to the next level". 

Pros: 
1. If you are good worker, you will be recognized (but NOT rewarded).
2. Flexibility for long distance commuters to work from home as needed. In fact their WFH policy is very good
3. Some of the managers are very caring. Be careful which team you get into
4. A lot of the software development happens in house so depending upon the team and team size, you will get to learn a lot of good technologies (Flex, Sencha, Big data tools etc.)
cons:
Cons:
1. In my experience, the Senior management is very partial towards the US and UK employees when they award promotion and rewards. Indian center is seen more as a BPO center. 
2. Managers only want to grow the team brlow them. Some of your peers will not even have half the experience as you do in same designation as you but perform one level lower
3. You are recognized by the number of people who report to you. Senior management should focus on not just hiring, but hiring good talent.
4. Projects should be tracked by managers as well as the upper management. Managers should own up for their team. Finger pointing is not the best way to tackle your subordinates.
5. Senior managements regards proximity as the only barometer for measuring performance.
6. Long working hours for India teams while US teams leave at 5 pm EST.
7. They don't recognize your value till you put down your papers. Exit interview by HR is a joke.
8.  Rewards come to those who either don't work OR are not smart enough but lucky OR  are intelligent enough to work AND have an obsequious eagerness to please the upper management

review_title: Great place to start one's career
pros: Working with relatively smart people on the institutional side. The culture generally open and cultivating. Training and benefits are good. Overall a good place to start one's career in one of the traditional key business areas.
cons: There tends to be frequent personnel reshuffling especially in front office of key businesses, which tends to redirect career paths. Juniors have very little say in which direction they want to build their career in. Different businesses have very different cultures, and some can be more difficult than others, so be careful what you are getting in to.

pros: Highly established stable reputed financial services organization. Strong culture that has driven the firm since many many years. Talent house. Lots of highly talented professionals in the firm driving the firm culture
cons: Although not impacting directly yet there is a slow but steady shake up of the historic firm culture partly influenced by acquisitions and partly by regulations. Lot of (sometimes lot more than necessary) focus on controls that is proving to be counter innovative in my mind

pros: 20 days PTO and surprisingly same level of health insurance benefit for all employees (good if you're a low level employee, not too much if you're a senior level
cons: No work life balance. You get reminded to take your leave but its only that it will look good statistically. Different policy treatments to different employees.

pros: I would highly recommend MS for folks coming out of business school. Most people in my associate class left after a few years or eventually after they were promoted to VP, so it is not a job that, in my experience, most people look to develop into a long-term career (there are certainly exceptions!). However, it does open up a lot of options for people who are interested in getting solid business and financial training and looking to  go into industry or do something else within finance. It was definitely worth the blood, sweat and tears, and I am happy to have done it.
cons: There is a lot of turnover at all levels.

review_title: Worst company it has become due Indian inc-competent crowd and inhumane crowd.
pros:
-You will get to work with investment bank and learn few things about finance domain.
-Good brand name Morgan has.
cons:
-Worst HR guys, 
- Super sad and low IQ technical panel unlike their other Divisions
-Project is OCT does not have any value
- Slog 24 hours
- No high pay unlike other Divisions
-HR is worst from scheduling drive till date, these guys pretend to be very smart but are biggest fools
-Morgan Stanley has now become a poor name in market due to miserable technical panel and the company is not aware.
-Atleast they should ask candidate for feedback even if he is not selected, so as to expose these crooks.

pros:
If youre good and dont let HR negociate you down as they try everyone, you can get a good pay
if youre a morgan robot theres a lot of advancement opportunities
cons:
VERY VERY stressful environment
watch out of youre a consultant, they will hire you then lower your salary months later then do it again the following year
they fire ppl every year if their numbers arent good
Gives many objectives and puts 100 roadblocks to achieve them then puts pressure
Non agile environment
Slow technology adoption, they customize their infra so much that they avoid going to latest techs
montreal office is ugly and cheap

review_title: First class business in a first class way
job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: great teamwork, great place to learn the business from very experienced managers.  real thrill of getting the deal done and winning in the market place, thinking like an owner makes a big company feel small.  Great brand name and trust that has been built with clients over many years.
cons: have to work a  lot of time.  Have to be careful about the managers whom you work for.  Also want to make sure you are on a good path to success and have appropriate feedback to determine what those paths are early on.

review_title: Not a place that it used to be
pros:
Flexibility in schedule
No hovering manager
Good investment options/platform
cons:
Pay structure is terrible and is constantly changing
Support from corporate support people is terrible
Upper management doesn't understand what is going on in the branches and they are killing morale.

pros: The overwhelming majority of the colleagues I have had the chance to work with are excellent professionals. There is a relatively strong meritocracy, although you have to be able to sell your work. There is a sense of true team work, and you can count on your colleagues if you need help. There are excellent opportunities for broadening your knowledge.
cons: The firm shows very different faces to its different employees in terms of comp and flexibility. It is a large firm with considerable admin overhead and inertia of processes, which you can feel on a daily basis.

review_title: I believe in the vision, but I also believe it dilutes the franchise.
pros: I get it.  We're going to do something different than Goldman.  And it's the right way forward for the broader business, with scalable, predictable revenues from wealth, from distribution, and from retail.
cons: Has anybody told that to the folks in Europe? Where the DNA is pure IB and sales and trading and the human capital and the platform deployed there is only good for that?  And to change it, you'll need to totally reconfigure the business?

job_title: Financial Advisor Associate in Tampa, FL
pros: Salary, plus partial commissions (25% of revenue) as long as you meet performance goals; which are impossible unless you have a book or are hired onto a team who will insure you meet your performance goals. Will pay you a salary while your studding for your licenses. If you fail you series 7, the first time you take it, your fired. So do take it seriously.
cons: No support of any kind. The interview is purely a sales pitch. Its your business. Do not look for any direction or support on how to succeed. The training is of no value unless you've never been a salesman; the training is exclusively sales training with no training on "how to" open accounts, build a portfolio, or basic investing (you will be left to learn that on your own). Corporate culture. Either you're in or not; if so, you must drink the punch. Very difficult to succeed. They will not hesitate in canning you; I saw four guys get the axe with no notice, just "today is your last day". When they cut you, that same day clients who believed in you enough to hire YOU and open an account with you, will be reassigned to senior guys. They will start calling every client the next day to inform them you are no longer with them. This is the made greed dash to take whatever clients you build while there. Every client I had refused to even talk to these guys out for a easy buck.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Great people - truly, they attract smart and pleasant people for the most part. The work is challenging, and it's easy to build marketable skills. If you can find a sponsor you will be promoted quickly.
cons: Managers aren't trained or coached, and don't know how to retain and motivate good people. Favoritism is apparent at comp time. For the money and hours, it ends up being the smart move to do a few years and rotate out of the company instead of building a career there. The company recently came off the friendly to working moms list.

pros: Extremely profession firm that has embraced the correct strategy for the new financial regime post the financial crisis.  Morgan Stanley has exceptional people who work very hard. The firm's culture is strong and healthy for young executives and entry level employees.
cons: The regulatory burden has changed this industry significantly. While the risk taking attitude of the banks has been removed, the dynamism and entrepreneurial spirit of the industry has also been removed along with it.  Morgan Stanley remains best in class under the new rules.

pros: Good pay and lots of different roles in the division
cons: Literally all talk and no action.  FID leadership changed while I was there with no change in company loyalty or performance.  Completely political atmosphere that swallows young people if your family or college lax team isn't well-connected enough.  HR is a complete joke with no support network.  I would highly recommend taking ANY other bulge bracket or even middle market FID offer if you want to feel like you are doing anything or are valued.

pros: Opened a lot of doors for me down the road. Learned how to be proficient with time.
cons: Really no training program for new hires. I went from intern to CSA after about a year but was never any on-boarding for my role which led to conflicts down the road. Pay was bad, didn’t change from intern role. Team culture was every man for themselves and those in the FAA program would often times try to go around their superiors and hand their work off to people on the team who really did not have the time.

job_title: Associate Professional in New York, NY
pros: Excellent suite of technology stack . Employees seem very dedicated in general . You will find plenty of time to  learn and “survive “  even if you are raw on some skills . Upper management has  vision
cons: Very poor , selfish middle managers .all over  the floors .Incompetent to lead teams , and carry the vision set by upper management . No career path for tech-oriented folks

review_title: Morgan Stanley is a great place to work if only for the name on your resume
job_title: Operations Associate in New York, NY
pros: The best reasons to work for Morgan Stanley are the prestige and weight that the name carries with it.  Even as an Operations Associate, a middle office role, I found that the name, Morgan Stanley, at the top of my resume opened doors for me and gained me respect.  This was invaluable when looking to expand my career and take steps towards a more fulfilling career.  Morgan Stanley's management is also a plus as they are highly intelligent people who will do whatever it takes to ensure the best interests of the firm.
cons: Risky business model and somewhat arrogant attitude

review_title: Traditional Investment Banking culture with exposure to many different areas of investing
pros: Exposure to myriad aspects of investing, good training, supportive culture, good work/life balance.  Town Hall meetings allowed employees to feel updated, and the MS Today home page helped to "shrink" the size of the organization and make it feel more local.
cons: Challenges typical to very large organizations -- efficiency can suffer b/c of many layers.  Comp not always competitive relative to smaller firms focused on just one area of investing (PE, hedge funds, asset management).

review_title: I love you, like I hate you.
pros: The place offers you brillant exposure and experience. I loved my job and was happy going to work each day. The work environment is very good but varies from teams to teams.
cons: It's a huge firm and you need to work really hard and long to work your way up. Due to lack of workforce, you may find yourself working really long hours and taking more responsibilities than what you get recognized for (unimportant side-work e.g. in technology projects).

pros: Lots of room to grow up. It is a huge organization, lateral moves to different teams and projects are always possible. Suite of developer productivity tools means less time solving IT issues, and more time solving business problems
cons: Very clearly a bank in culture. Technology adoption moves slowly, although they have been trying to improve this. You'll encounter lots managers who have little-to-no tech skills. Once past VP, keeping abreast of technology trends seems to be looked down upon

pros: Come in, do your job, go home.  Hours are reasonable (8:30-6), so this place is good for people with children who want to go home to their wife.
cons: Slow promotions, tiny bonuses, little opportunity for advancement.  But I was working in commodities, which is nearly closed (whole sub-departments are sold off or shut down).

review_title: As an FAA, you are required to take and pass all exams, and bring in and manage 3-5 MM annually to keep your seat.
job_title: Financial Advisor Associate in Winter Park, FL
pros: They provide you with plenty of access, and equipment to get the job done, they don't care whether you come or go, as long as you produce
cons: Don't dare asking them for help, as you won't get it. Because they only care about the money you bring in, they don't really care too much on how you're doing day to day

review_title: The level of open and overt racism at Morgan Stanley is bad
pros: The benefits to staff are really good.
cons:
We are made to attend all these diversity event but in reality this is just a tick the box.

review_title: Rookie advisor received great training, long lasting relationships.

review_title: Decent company whether you are on the sales, operations or other department.

review_title: Keeping a job through the recession. Many people in finance don't like their jobs.

review_title: MS in a nutshell from an IT perspective
job_title: Associate Software Engineer Developer in New York, NY
pros:
Lots of smart people who are very hardworking. They come from a variety of backgrounds and always give their best efforts.

Employees and consultants are treated pretty much the same. If you're doing any kind of IT work, everyone is pretty much standardized and work is delegated based on technology and business experience. If you want to get the "best" work, you have to know everything about it beforehand.

Compensation is good and also guaranteed. I used to work in an IB that didn't give me bonuses due to the small size of my team and my rank. MS gives you a cut end of story, but that doesn't mean it's good. Benefits are also good. You get decent coverage from the basic medical plans offered.

Depending on your team and nature of your project, the work from home policy is pretty lax. A lot of co-workers have families and commute into the city so sometimes they need to be home.
cons:
Work can get repetitive. Many times I find myself doing a glorified refactoring of poorly written or poorly planned code. You'd think there would be an extensive process in check to prevent poor code from going into production, but that's not the case. Teams need to enforce their own code review and audit policies and sometimes that's difficult when you are trying to hit big deadlines.

IT support staff could use some work. There are no doubt talented individuals who keep good notes and are very good at drilling down issue solutions, but that doesn't save QA overall from being a giant sink. I think the QA teams need to be closely situated with the developers and create their test-cases co-dependently so they can actually understand the software; otherwise, developers may as well be the first point of contact.

Ranking and compensation improvement is slow. There's a big bureaucracy in place for promotions and it can be very frustrating to work year after year without seeing any improvement. Getting ahead requires you to be very social which is not always the easiest thing to do.

review_title: VP- IT in algo trading. Sweatshop... All stick, no carrot.
job_title: Vice President- ISGT in New York, NY
pros:
You work with smart people- there is a comraderie in being underpaid and overworked. The work was often fairly interesting, and what you did mattered- you learn that all too well the first time you make a mistake. 

Its easy to get promoted. If you are reasonably competent, you are pretty much guaranteed to be a VP in 5 years!
cons:
Stress is off the walls. In the algo trading group, you have billions of dollars pushing through your systems every day. Thousands of boxes, dozens of strategies, tons of connections. So much can go wrong. Yet the pay is mediocre- most guys on my team did not get a bonus or got a token bonus (under $3000) in the previous 3-5 years. 

The IT division is 70% consultants. The consultants get paid on a day basis, so that means the remaining full timers get stuck with all the weekend work because they don't want to pay consultants. So if there is some kind of release, server upgrade, network change that needs to be verified, its all on the remaining guys- and that 30% that is left also includes managers, who won't be joining you on those calls. 

The red tape is torturous. On one side you have your managers and business counterparts who are all over you to get a change out, and on the other side you have this vast machine who  is pushing hard against you to force you to fight to get it out. 

Every year there is a new excuse as to why the bonuses were non-existent. ROE is too low, Earnings are up, but revenue isn't... its all a bunch of BS, IT is a cost center, and they aren't getting paid, regardless of whether you are some kind of server monkey or in the front office writing strategies.

job_title: IT Senior Associate in London, England
pros: I've always enjoyed the fact that MS really is a tech-driven bank that sees technology as the driving factor, as opposed to a cost. The firm is willing to fund major multi-year cross-division technical initiatives, and the collaboration that comes with this makes for an exciting work environment
cons: The sheer amount of bespoke libraries that one has to use during development mean that there is a relatively steep initial learning curve to become familiar with the development practices, and there are multiple layers between your code and the raw object you want to interact with, which sometimes incurs significant costs when trying to figure out how to do something in a "morganised" way

review_title: The pros and cons of being huge
pros: Morgan Stanley has a superb technical infrastructure which allows software engineers to develop, deploy and maintain software around the world with ease.
cons: Morgan Stanley is a huge, regulated company (more the 50,000 employees) and with that comes all of the problems of trying to manage such a huge organization. For example, large amounts of time every year are spent dealing the review process. Another issue is the extreme control the firm must, by regulation, apply to their technology infrastructure.

pros: Working at Morgan Stanley provides a great opportunity to learn from smart people, work on interesting projects, and take on substantial responsibilities
cons: Respect for personal time is pretty low for analysts and associates.   Groups across the company are understaffed and because no one expects analysts and associates to stick around for very long (on average), they are overworked while they are there.

job_title: Digital Strategy in New York, NY
pros: The actual tasks you're required to do are simple (if not simplistic). You often work regular 9-5 hours. Most people are satisfied by strings of buzzwords in meetings.
cons:
The entire marketing organization has little to no cohesion. Groups are siloed to the point where people on the same floor—or in some cases, the same team—don't know the same details for both small and major projects. That, and the department heads have zero marketing background, and therefore are not in a position to actually create dynamic strategies.

If you want to build a portfolio-worthy career in marketing, digital content, or content strategy, look elsewhere. 

There's a reason many people stay at Morgan Stanley for 10-15 years: they simply don't have the requisite skills to go somewhere else.

review_title: One of the best financial firms to work with
job_title: Financial Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There is not a financial product or service that the firm cannot offer. The technology is second to none. At the end of the day if you want to build a successful business, there are not too many other firms that offer what MS has.
cons: Because the firm is so big, it is basically run by lawyers with many managers operating from the standpoint of not losing their job. I miss the days when it was smaller and local managers could make things happen. No longer unfortunately.

review_title: I enjoy working here but feel powerless on the big issues
pros:
Many passionate software devs who really want to make a difference.

Good social scene in Calgary with many employee-organized clubs like board game nights, chess club, fantasy hockey, playing soccer in at the park, etc.

Free beer on Friday.

Calgary office had a great location near Prince's Island Park and Kensington. Is attached to the +15 network for those days with really bad weather.

Teams are self-organizing and you can affect a lot of change there.
cons:
Some developers have grown complacent and do not want to improve, making working with them frustrating.

Managers are overloaded. Too many meetings and too many reports to effectively manage them all. Some developers have 1-on-1s with their manager much less often than others.

Senior to intermediate to junior developer ratio feels skewed. Difficult to find mentorship. Not enough oversight on implementation and code reviews for teams composed of juniors and newer intermediates.

Three years of focus on new features coupled with the above have led to insane amounts of tech debt. No communicated plan to pay off this tech debt.

Executives do a poor job living the company's espoused values. E.g. despite Transparency being a 'core value' a big change like the QA department being abolished was never communicated beforehand, leading to a great deal of stress and uncertainty and some high-performing QA analysts leaving the company.

Being acquired by Morgan Stanley, a company deeply involved in the subprime mortgage crisis, does not feel good. I liked working for a Canadian company and feeling proud of my employer.

Vision benefit is getting better in 2020, but paramedical practitioner benefit is becoming much, much worse if you visit two or more types (e.g. massage, physiotherapy)

Quality of your experience varies greatly depending on your manager and product owner. Good ones are able to help manage client expectations and your workload, while inexperienced ones lead to you feeling overworked and underwater.

review_title: A culture of high performers that recognizes & rewards the best.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY

review_title: Stay away from the RFE Program unless you are a sales superstar.

review_title: Great FICC capital markets starting ground for first 3-5 yrs. Freedom to advance in sales or trading.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Jersey City, NJ

review_title: Great place to start a career

It combines the information from multiple classes into one fast-paced internship. Great name and knowledge on your resume and helpful in deciding if investing and finance is a direction interested in.
cons: The quarter I participated was very unorganized and demanded too much of full time students in such a condensed time. Culture and people was a strange mix and not the friendliest.

pros:
1. Responsibility given on day one.
2. A lot of mobility across divisions within the back office - both geographically and functionally.
3. No hierarchy in the company. You can speak your thoughts any time.
cons:
1. Personal development totally depends on the team you're in and who your manager is. Sometimes management are not very supportive and interested in your personal development.
2. Very rigid in academic performance for Graduate students. Cannot get a return offer if you missed a 2:1.
3. Training is quite poor.

review_title: Great name on your resume,great work experience
pros: The job is interesting and a great introduction to the world of investing. You will learn a lot from the brokers, the work you do and the processes that take place in Wealth Management.
cons: It's kind of a dead end job but there are a few opportunities to climb up or apply elsewhere. You're looked at pretty highly at commercial banks so you may be able to leverage that.

pros: Pretty good graduate training program for Technology that takes place in New York and London. Great employee benefits. The work really depends on what team you get in. The infrastructure they have is really good, but it is pretty closed from the outside so you might have to work with slightly out-dated technologies, that has to be approved.
cons: Too much investment in JVM ecosystem and everything is driven by how profitable it is. The technology is secondary to business.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Some very high-caliber talent at all levels.  Overall tone is supportive.  High standards, which is good for the career.  Not mean-spirited.  Not a sweatshop. Reasonably good benefits. Convenient midtown NYC location.
cons: Nepotisim and hiring of old cronies is more rampant here than at other Wall Street firms; this limits the potential of others who are not in the "in crowd.".  Only a very few women at the top.  Those who made it have either been around for decades or have met extraordinarily high hurdles.

job_title: IT Associate in New York, NY
pros: Work-life superior, Military Supportive, Pay and benefits excellent.  Many opportunities for growth and moving around business units. Ability to work independently as well as within teams.
cons: High stress, evaluations not often delivered, lack of communication regarding career advancement opportunities.

job_title: Executive Director in New York, NY
pros: As a company I have found that they excel at creating strong bonds between employees and have definitely succeeded in creating an environment where success of the team is more important than individual success. The net effect is that the working environment is excellent and that cross department & rank discussions are frequent and frank.
cons: The company is often more risk averse than its peers so this can make innovation more challenging. Their compensation structure means that long tenured employees lose out and the only effective way to be baselined to the market is to leave (and possibly rejoin).

review_title: Seven Month Background Check, misleading statements.
job_title: Financial Advisor Associate in Bellevue, WA
pros: The company made this seem like a great career move, decent benefits, okay salary. They promised a trip to New York. They make some enticing promises.
cons: The company misled me about the duration of the background check, telling me in March it would take 2-4 weeks. Then they said it in June, July, August... I passed background, however they starved me for months on false promises, and they were doing background checks well past the employment offer date. Then they acted like I was at fault. This is the most dishonorable company I have ever had the displeasure of working with.

job_title: Financial Advisor Associate in Chicago, IL
pros: It was a good entry-level job for resume building and the program taught you how to give good meetings. It was a sink or swim style that kept you on your toes.
cons: There were 0 vacation days, 0 days off, extremely high quotas you would need to reach so your commission kicks in.

review_title: Decent Company with great employee perks
pros:
- one of the top financial companies that are doing well recently, which means increase in bonuses each year
- maternity leave of 4 months 
- employee perks such as free access to prime museums and discounts in shows and movies
- great cafeteria with affordable prices
- sophisticated gym in the headquarters with discounted membership fees
- free flu shots available during winter
cons:
- depending on department and team, it can get very political
- getting promoted means getting people outside of your team to like you and consider you important

review_title: Breakdown of the structure at the MSVA(Morgan Stanley Virtual Advisory Center)
job_title: Registered Client Service Associate in Temple Terrace, FL
pros:
-20+ days of PTO
-A lot of flexibility with your schedule
cons:
- Managers here are hit or miss I’m saying that on the basis that most of us have had every single manager here due to disorganization and restructuring. Some managers really want to see you grow while others don’t mind letting you sit in your role until you burn out and leave.

- A lot of disorganization and misinformation, a lot of having to lie to clients because the firm doesn’t want you to tell them why something is being done to their account.

- I would go on but I rather give advice. If you’re considering working here as a licensed agent and you’re unlicensed, my advice would be to come in and study really hard every day because if you don’t pass your test you’re pretty much fired I’ve seen this done with over 20+ employees. So study really hard and get licensed and then once you’re licensed I would start looking for another place to work. If you are licensed I would avoid this place all together. Take my advice however you want.

review_title: If you are looking for work-life balance this is the place.
pros: The best thing about Morgan Stanley is the work-life balance and there's no micromanagement.  The manager is very lenient about the times you come in as a Technology associate as long as you get the work done.  You also get a company blackberry which has its own pros and cons.
cons: Quite a lot of politics so you really have to kiss ass if you want to move up faster.  Generally the people are smart but to really get things done you need connections or people will move at a snail's pace.

review_title: Look through the curtains and change your mind...its ok.
pros: The only reason to work at firm like this is to know that you have a job in these trying times. The benefits are great but you need them because with hours you work getting sick will become the norm.
cons: You will sacrifice you personal life, family time, outside interests, and possibly your health working long stressful hours in this environment. This may not seem like much but if once in you realize that you are not a "culture" fit you may really hate it.

review_title: They try to make the best for you
pros: Good working environment, you can move jobs easily (usually you need to spend 2 years in one position), they learn your preferences and help you with them (eg. moving to another location, moving to another team, make the working time flexible), not all the time of course but within their limits, they always help. Career and development opportunities.
cons: Demanding and stressful. If you want to reduce these, you need to work extra times. At the same time they are promoting to contribute to charities and volunteer jobs outside of the firm, sometimes feels like it was compulsory but with the extra working hours the question is: when?

review_title: Great company. Meritocracy. Diverse culture of excellence.
pros: Morgan Stanley is committed to diversity.  They are very supportive of developing new careers.  Access to senior management.  Will help and encourage you to get involved in locally to "give back." An outstanding brand.  A company you are proud to work for.
cons: Not a Con- But setting expectations:  New employees (especially those out of college) need to be prepared to work their way up the ladder.  If you expect to come in and be treated like a Managing Director with direct access to the CEO, you will be dissapointed (And you are maybe a bit dillusional).

pros: The brand name of the organization and the reach they have.  Opens up a lot of doors as generally everyone is willing to take a call from Morgan Stanley and do business with them.
cons: High pressure environment, a lot of competitive type-A over achievers as peers and in the last few years the culture has become a lot more political as well.

pros: Meritocracy and the best technology company on wall street. Exciting projects and minimal red tape. Great investment in technology and good collaboration with the business.
cons: Salary is not competitive. Too many senior management people making it hard for star performers to get promoted. Sometimes the work pressure can be a little too much.

pros: Good people, nice benefits, great community service involvement.
cons: Did not share the wealth, constantly boasted about Financial Advisors being the top 100 in the nation meanwhile the back office operations areas gave minimal salary increases to it's employees if any.   Also, their in-house technology is approximately 10-12 years behind it's competitors, although when I left they were're preparing for an upgrade.  Very little room for advancement without a license and even with a series 7 it's no guarantee of success.

pros: Good group of people. Good mobility opportunities, able to network across departments. Many long-term employees, and nice improved canteen
cons: Very difficult to get the visibility and exposure required for promotion. Need to belong to the  club. Promotion comes with a title change only  so no incentive to take on more responsibility and risk unless that itself moves you personally. If you are happy with staying in the same seat it's a great place

pros: I learned a lot in the process of becoming an Financial Advisor. Taking something so overly complex, and being able to simplify for my clients. I can now do that with my own finances, and happy to help friends and ensure they are not getting ripped on commissions.
cons: Terrible FAA program. Does not set their team up for success, unrealistic expectations. Nearly all advisors solely focused on padding their own pockets and not concerned about fees being charged to clients. It was really eye opening for me and disappointing. I left the industry, but if I had stayed - I would have gone to Fidelity or Betterment, companies that actually care about their clients whether you have $1000 to invest, or 5MM.

review_title: Excellent developers with a fantastic environment
pros: Incredible co-workers, flexible work hours, huge opportunities to learn how to work in a legacy system and move it into the future. Great social scene in Calgary with employees organizing many different events (chess, mtg, soccer, etc.). Managers are very active on isolating developers from the clients allowing more time for focused development and providing a relatively stress-free environment. Salaries and benefits are competitive. Senior employees are helpful and easy to approach.
cons: Legacy system can be painful to work with and without a large amount of domain knowledge adding large features can be tricky.

pros: A low benchmark by peers means it's relatively easy to do well. Pay very well for median performance and even better for great performance. Some charismatic leaders. Leading user of technology. Global standardised accounting protocals are a tribute to the great work by Trevor Harris and Vaughn Harvey.
cons: Highly political, although that's the norm for the industry. Global approach means a lot of boring travel. Research has been emasculated in recent years. Hedge fund clients now run the strategy for the securities division. Poor IBD deal flow makes it harder to get corporate access.

pros: Morgan Stanley is a great place to work because it provides a motivated team environment, with ample opportunity for advancement, and lots of access to clients early in your career. The company also offers a good compensation policy and competitive benefits relative to its peers. Employees are self starters and intelligent from junior levels to senior levels. In my experience, the firm provides great access to senior team members. More of a team approach than at many other banks - everyone works together across divisions to achieve the best results for clients.
cons: As in most banking positions, working at Morgan Stanley in investment banking requires long hours and a lack of schedule predictability.

review_title: Some good, some bad -- a great place for an experienced broker.
pros: Outstanding research and analysis assist the advisors with job performance.
cons: Financial Advisor training is primarily focused on sales with little information on products and strategies.  It's hard to be good at sales if you can't carry on a discussion about strategies for longer than 5 minutes.  Their efforts to save money will have a long term negative impact.

review_title: Decent place to start a carreer
job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The company is a global leader, one of the strongest players in the US brokerage market.  Clients are diverse and  the company offers a lot of learning opportunities.  Since the JV with MS the culture changes, as no longer being part of almost failed CITI. Benefits are good and comp is on par.
cons: Very long hours. The JV has caused a lot of technology problems, as most of the resources are devoted to the final systems to be seen in 2-3 years, while current tech infrastructure is suffering from poor India tech help and lack of on site tech personal.

review_title: Overall good place to work for
pros: New emphasis on work life balance has made the company a much better place to work for. For a large organisation the management structure seems pretty flat and senior management still seem reasonably accessible and in touch with the business.
cons: Too many IT projects lead by non IT people makes for a lot of poorly designed disjointed systems which leads to a lot of inefficiency.

pros:
The usual:

1. WFH when needed
2. Variable office timings (dependent on you manager really)
3.  unlimited sick leaves

Every January your BP shoots up as your performance never really matters in ensuring a good feedback or even retaining your job! It's how the business function does.

So, switch the business function the moment you realize it is making losses. If you can't get mobility, switch the company before they let you go.

review_title: Great place to work but Pay will be off market if you stay long

So in all good place to be for 3-4 years and then take a call

review_title: Great place to work, very satisfied...
job_title: Financial Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: the management is great, and working environment is very professional.  everyone is very nice, helpful, and most have the same goal to help the firm grow.  each day is different, as you never know what to expect and the employees are very fun to be around.  makes coming to work each morning very enjoyable.
cons: sometimes difficult to have time off...RFE program is well-thought out, but it can be extremely difficult to obtain the top levels in order to achieve your bonuses.  not much guidance is given aside from self taught / instructional videos you watch online.

review_title: Work with the best, get paid well but you will give an awful lot in return for your rewards.

review_title: Will look good on your resume

job_title: Registered Client Service Associate in Baltimore, MD

pros: Good company to work for. You could build a good career and work till retirement with satisfaction. This is a employee friendly organization and place to be if you are planning long term career.

review_title: Morgan Stanley was a great place to work... for some people. Most of the people were great but I also experienced racism

review_title: Constant learning experience with extensive autonomy

review_title: Not for everyone, but if you do well, you'll be happy

review_title: Recently deposed IT staffer tells all
job_title: IT Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: Huge, innovative global investment bank with a good reputation. Technology is cutting edge and excellent for an organization that size. Despite market turmoil company is solid and well managed. Growth opportunities exist but usually only for newcomers. Desirable locations for offices to work in.
cons:
Unfortunately many. The biggest downside is lack of security. In my 2 + years there I witnessed severe attrition and laying off. While I can't pretend to know what was going on in each business unit, it did seem that the people who had been with the firm the longest were the first to go. Some well known departments were wiped out and replaced almost entirely. I suspect this is to avoid paying an accruing pension and because of "job performance". The ruthless bankers and managers seemed to be the only ones that survived. Ruthless business I understand, but I've met plenty of successful people who didn't resort to ruthlessness to survive. 
I would also have to complain about some of the middle management. Some of the people chosen to serve in the ranks of middle management were flat out incompetent. My department was re-orged entirely, I was told my job had been outsourced, so I went out and got a better job. Some who decided to stay on got fired instead of a new job as a consultant. 
All in all, it's a big name shop and if you can get in it's a good place to work, but like a lot of other big name companies, be a little leery of what is "promised" at your interview. You will pay dues no matter where you come from, you will probably not make as much as you thought, and after years of dedication you will probably get pinched. Wish I could be more optimistic but I saw several senior bankers in full crisis mode after losing their jobs when they were obviously planning on retiring from the company. I realize times have changed, but Morgan Stanley doesn't even pretend to honor your time spent there, and to me that kind of sucks.

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The compensation is better than most Wall St. firms.  At Morgan Stanley you will find out quickly that they want to retain their own talent.  Most of the big competing firms do not treat their employees as well as Morgan Stanley.
cons: There are almost always long hours, especially during busy season. Some of the work that you do on a very daily basis is not the most intellectually rewarding.  Moving up in the company sometimes has more to do with the amount of hours you put in, rather than your potential.

review_title: The brand is better than the experience.
job_title: Executive Director in New York, NY
pros:
The Morgan Stanley brand is well received and respected in the market.
Global footprint provides exposure to a broad array of markets and products.
Best in class in terms of managing data.
Smart co-workers who are always willing to collaborate.
Excellent remote computing capabilities.
Excellent use of collaboration tools.
cons:
The Firm is on a systemic downward death spiral caused inconsistent vision and poor execution.  

Prior to the merger of Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter, Morgan Stanley was one of the most elite firms in Financial Services.  Since the merger the Firm was suffered a perpetual identity crisis.  It oscillates back and forth between wanting to be a retail brokerage Firm or a trading shop.  Unfortunately the oscillations happen at a frequency that never allows the Firm successfully realize the vision of leaders.  As such the Firm is not the best at either.  Currently the Firm is focused on Retail as evidenced by it's acquisition of 51% of Smith Barney.  The merger is at least a year behind schedule and excessively over budget.  From an earnings perspective the Firm has not been able to put together two successive quarters of positive results.  Each earnings report is laden with reasons to justify its inconsistent performance.  The Firm does not seem to know how the grow revenue so it is trying to improve profitability by contracting expenses.  This is being achieved by continuously reducing head count, benefits, salaries and capital investments.  Are these changes working?  No, the stock price is down 18% year to date, moral is down, and our ability to attract top talent is diminishing.  

Prediction: the Firm is acquired within 12-18 months.

review_title: Learned a lot and gained valuable, industry experience.

review_title: Great place to learn the ins and outs of the financial services industry....

job_title: Financial Advisor in New York, NY
pros: Top-notch in terms of available resources, from firm technology to market research to investment models/managers/products.  Strong reputation and brand recognition.  Reasonable incentive-based revenue model.
cons: Very little (if any) guidance or mentoring to incoming financial advisors, especially in re: prospecting and building a book of business. review_title: Great learning experience...may not be where you stay
pros: Fantastic opportunity to learn about a broad range of investment products from a major wirehouse, opportunities to learn from many different Financial Advisors how to run a practice
cons:
Typically you must support between 3-5 highly demanding Financial Advisors, and all of their corresponding clients.  The company's way of managing teams is highly irregular.  Most companies allow feedback of all colleagues on a team.  However, here they only "manage" support staff, rather than also allowing for colleagues to provide feedback about Financial Advisors.  However, Advisors are able to give feedback about their support staff.
Management never solicits feedback from support staff about Financial Advisors, so depending on whom you work for, your life could be miserable and management doesn't take steps to bring that in line, nor solicit feedback from others.  Basically, the only time you will work directly with your manager is when you come in for a review annually, where you're told what your current Financial Advisors think of you. 
(Which is the only time you'll ever work with your manager--NO "one-on-ones" quarterly like at other firms, no coaching, no growth opportunities.  As a support staff member, you'll only hear what your Financial Advisors say about you--but they aren't your managers, they aren't trained HR professionals, and you'll only hear what they say about you from your manager.  
Its a very odd dynamic, in that everyone doesn't just all get in the same room and talk about team dynamics at all, and how to improve them.
It's incredibly strange.

pros: Perks, free coffe,... needed to type at least 5 words in this field.
cons:
Custom systems with no market value. Stay long time and it would be difficult to work elsewhere. 

Security constrains are killing creativity.

Layoffs are targeting older employees now. Don't count on retiring in this company.    

Salary used to be competitive but not anymore. 

Lies are tolerated from managers, which are constantly plotting how to take advantage / advance their careers by using you as a tool.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: I have not seen anything that's a pro during my time at Morgan Stanley
cons: Hire and Fire Culture (Team had layoffs i 7 of last 9 years); Management Lies to get things done; Wont keep promises made in writing; Politics; Work Life Balance is a Myth; HR and Management works in silo and point fingers at each other;

review_title: 5 Stars for Company, but Depends on Team
job_title: Data Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Worldwide name recognition, good company brand
Free Morgan Stanley Online account (refundable ATM fees!)
401K
Good vacation policy (20 days prorated)
Flexible WFH schedule depending on group
The CEO is really outstanding
Great MDs in Technology
cons: Since there are thousands of teams at MS and each team is different, I have rated MS as a company 5 stars. However, for the Analytics & Data group, in particular, I believe there are many things to work on. For one, half of the team is non-technical and brought in to be "trained" to be technical, but it ends up being that the technical people do all of the work for the non-technical people and then the non-technical people take the credit for the work. There are also a lot of work politics at play with half of the employees on the team either having dads that work at MS in other departments or as clients of MS's WM division. If you point out inefficiencies or things to work on, some leadership may take this personally and start attacking your work. Micromanagement is abundant and people get promoted very easily due to power and network. There is also racism at play at times as I have seen people treat those based out of another country as lesser.

review_title: Good company, but future in doubt
pros: Job satisfaction, good legacy, decent technology, at least not merged with Wachovia...thank goodness!  I think John Mack is a good leader, good communicator, and very blunt (which is kind of nice).
cons: Lack of control of what happens with the company and it being in the news.  Right now their future as a Morgan Stanley brand is in question due to all the mergers.  Tough to work in this industry when you don't know what is going on (although Mack has tried to keep us informed).

job_title: Wealth Management Intern in Beverly Hills, CA
pros: A large company, with an intimate feel, can teach you a lot about asset allocation and wealth management. The internship post I had allowed me to be directly involved with clients and solving everyday problems.
cons: I would definitely say its still a competitive place to work in. It gets incredibly busy and people are not okay with excuses, when something is asked to be done it is to be done. That's true of any industry, but morgan stanly does demand excellence

pros: Morgan Stanley is an excellent company to further develop your skills and add to your experience. The company recognises the quality of work produced by individuals and will do their utmost to develop them. I was advanced to a manager role within 12 months of joining the company so it has been great in terms of career progression.
cons: The work hours can be long at times especially during busy season but I suppose this is the norm for any large company.

review_title: Solid development environment and resources, middling business interaction
job_title: Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
- Great software development platform for Java devs; pretty much everything you need is one Ivy-import away
- IT is given respect in terms of their input on improving the running-the-bank functions
cons:
- There is always a tiresome communication gap between the business users (your customers as a software dev) and yourself
- Seriously heavyweight middle-management; devs are often outnumbered (to the scale of 3:1, in the worst cases) by 'project managers' of some form or another projects
