cons: Low payouts for financial advisors when you are just starting out.  Small salary is based on regions.  Big push to sell more Morgan stanley products than other products which creates a conflict of interest if you are trying to put the client's interest first.

pros: Morgan Stanley offered an excellent summer analyst experience and gave me exposure to the financial markets. I learned through close mentorship and built relationships that will last the rest of my career.
cons: Long hours and lack of work of work life balance. Lack of sleep was definitely an issue. I need to fill more words in so here we go.

job_title: Trade Confirmations Back Office in Glasgow, Scotland
pros:
Good exposure for early on in career,
A lot of responsibility if you show willing and approachable senior management with open floor policy.
cons: Very High staff turnover probably due to low pay in back office, a lot being out sourced slowly to India, Glasgow office will soon be just the control centre and senior staff not very knowledgeable in back office.

pros: Great culture and made some good friends there. The work was interesting and worked with some incredibly talented employees. Nice new building with a good canteen.
cons: No career progression, grad job only in Glasgow. Sometimes working hours are awful, even for ops, and interns despite being told that they are like graduates are not respected in the same way at all.

job_title: Institutional Equity Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
This is a great place to work, the headquarters is fantastic though the trading floor is a bit dark but it is dynamic and filled with extremely intelligent people. 

Diverse groups of teams within institutional equity with the ability to work across the division
cons:
Given the level of intelligence of the workforce on occasion people can be snappy or condescending 

Not all floors of the headquarters are renovated so major floors of revenue generating businesses are it of date

review_title: "Appreticeship model code for Old Boys Club"
pros: Standard (slightly lower) pay for Wall Street IB. Great training for any finance job and presentation exposure to executives at dozens of companies.
cons: Look at MS IB leadership...clear culture of passive non-promotion through not staffing visa workers/women/minorities on large deals. Small deals take the same amount of effort but are not valued for longterm group advancement. Compared to GS, JPM, BA, Citi, client teams are small, resulting in overworked analysts, associate are slightly better paid analysts. and VPs do associate work as well as develop clients.

job_title: Managing Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: Used to be the name. Unfortunatly Morgan has lost its cache. The brand advantage has evaporated. Technology is lagging and talent departure is unfotunate.
cons: Managment has lost all connectivity and they have forced out the best managers. There is no meritocracy. In tough times the good ole boy network really kicks in. Most seior managers only care about saving their jobs. No dissent is tolerated and the guys we knew and could count on in tough times are all gone to UBS

review_title: Looks Good on Resume but Beware
pros: 20 days vacation, Liberal Sick policy, Prestigious NAME; Tuition Reimbursement
cons: Mandatory 10 day vacation;  Lack of good management;High turnover; No transparency around promotion requirements; Promotions are granted once a year to the entire company; 401K match is allocated at the end of the year the company's stock fund instead of your fund designations; Unorganized; Terrible technology;

job_title: Wealth Management Intern in Boca Raton, FL
pros: Brand recognition, competitive salary and benefits, access to proprietary research and information, company database provides contact information and access to top employees, low-stress working envronment
cons: You are a number. Management saw new recruits at a burden, rather than an asset. was assigned menial tasks, and denied requests to take on projects, Financial Advisors are narrowly focused on their own business- minimal cooperation and social interaction in office.

job_title: Overlay Portfolio Manager in New York, NY
pros: Firm has a good reputation.  Merger has created opportunities for creative problem solving.  Firm has good benefits and good research.
cons: Difficult to move up in the organization.  Have to be willing to consider a lateral move.  Not very good at promoting and recognizing employees for work they have done that is above their normal duties.

pros: Working for them looks good on a resume. They promote taking the 9 & 10 series exams. You don't have to worry building your own book of business.
cons: Micro management, not able to create your own schedule. Management doesn't know how to properly lead competent individuals. To many co-workers willing to stab you in the back.

pros: A job with a paycheck
cons: Transitioning the two companies will be rough - already noticing communication isnt what it should be leading up to the critical change over.  Management is overwhelmed and over worked.  Pricing changes (commissions, payout, fees, etc) have lead to dissatisfied employees and clients.

pros: Reputation of MSSB, career advancement, huge range of products and services offered, huge range of access to research, MSSB has a global advantage
cons: It is such a large company, with so many other employees, Australia offices are not as large when compared with other local broking firms; sometimes a lot of "layers" to get through to get something done.

review_title: Lots of opportunity if you are in the right clique
pros: Great benefits - twenty days of vacation.  360 degree review process is beneficial for self improvement.  Lots of online training courses available for self education.
cons: Sr. Management can be arrogant and rude.  This filters down as acceptable behavior to the remaining staff.  It can be very challenging to work across groups or divisions with this attitude.

pros: One of the most recognized brands in the world.  Unlimited potential if you have someone who believes in you.
cons: There is little effort made toward attracting, cultivating and retaining talent.  Performance matters, but not how you got there.  They tend to reward risky behavior and good luck over conservative good money management skills

pros: Premier investment bank.  Intelligent, driven and supportive colleagues.  Interesting and challenging work.
cons: Mobility can be difficult within the firm.  This was not the case years ago.  Each division of the firm has a different culture and feel - it is not unified.  Compensation at higher levels is deferred for 3 years.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in South Jordan, UT
pros: Good amount of financial knowledge gained, lots of opportunity to grow in financial industry
cons: My position was a call center, I was responsible for a large amount of information and guidance on various issues from retirement, new accounts, banking, and web support.  This created a very stressful environment at times due to the complexities of each of these large lines of business

pros: Looks good on your resume and there are lots of young people working here if you're just starting out.
cons: The most intelligent analysts leave within 2 years, the department was severely understaffed, even senior managers have little to no power and have to seek approval for every decision (no matter how minor) with the New York Office. If you want to work where the decisions are being made, work in New York.

review_title: Great Company -- if you liked the former Soviet Union
pros: Excellent opportunities for those who enjoy the status quo and love hierarchy.  If you enjoy delegating to outsourcing companies this is the right place for you!
cons:
1) IT management that knows little about IT
2) Technical expertise  is rarely recognized or rewarded.
3) Anemic pay raises and bonuses
4) Cronyism and nepotism
5) MS technology that places layers on top of develop that are difficult to understand.
6) QA teams run by clueless management, many of whom never wrote a test case in their loves.   Only the bottom layer of the pyramid actually does any real work.

job_title: Training Program Manager in Shoreline, WA
pros: Provides good benefits and pay.  Large company with focus on internal promotion and cross training opportunities.  Open to remote working arrangements in some cases.
cons: Large company so have to navigate a lot of "red tape" to move initiatives forward.  Ever changing industry success factors result in reduction of force cycles that are larger than in other industries.

pros: Great colleagues with huge knowledge, lots of internal trainings, lot to learn regarding the infrastructure and solutions. Overall it’s a very great place!
cons: Local management was very poor. There were a lot to improve not sure if it has changed or not. Also there were way too many mandatory meetings and conference calls - it was challenging to focus on actual work.

pros: Good Work if you get a good team. Solid Culture and core values, Tech and Data is best among financial services companies. Good amount of smart and driven geeks reside in Morgan Stanley.
cons: All cons of an MNC and lots of processes, constraints on browsing the internet, contributing back to open source and security constraints as the financial data is very important that social network data.

review_title: Good starting position with decent operational exposure
pros: Fast past work environment that gives you an opportunity to interact with MS CSRs/ front office out of New York, MS IT department, hedge funds clients, and of course other middle/back office operational groups.

pros: Great platforms for investment vehicles and programs for clients

job_title: Financial Advisor Associate in Anchorage, AK
pros: There name. It's a big name to an extent more people are familiar with Merrill lynch in anchorage. The branch manager in anchorage is very helpful.
cons: Very little guidance or resources coupled with super High hurdles  with limited time and constant pressure you will be fired. Race and gender issues.

pros: Smart people to work with, good team environment and culture. Pretty good 401K match plan
cons: Work from home although encouraged by the company is largely frowned upon by direct management. Unless you’re an ED or above the comps are a joke. Health benefits are merely average. Internal mobility is like a golden unicorn - one hears about it (a lot) but it doesn’t exist

review_title: Don't take it too seriously.  You'll never get out alive.

There are many ways to make a dollar in this world, so you should strongly question why you've chosen this place to make yours.  Also, no one is good looking.

review_title: Connection and relevance are keys at Morgan Stanley

cons: Lack of vision and strategy, especially for the IT department.  Layoff of many, many good people and reduction of expenses has created a difficult environment and morale is suffering.  Many good people have left due to the recent and current situation.

job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY
pros: working with intelligent and world-class individuals.
cons: Poor management of people. Disheartening to see people that knowhow to play office politics succeed over people that have truly worked hard to get where they are. Many people exude a sense of entitlement...

pros: Great team to work for, wonderful people to work with, as well as tons of opportunities for professional growth if you can struggle through the boring stuff in the beginning.
cons: Micromanagement can be a serious problem.  Also, routine is always a killer.  Also, sometimes I wish MS would eliminate a lot of overlapping managerial positions that it currently has because it sucks to be reporting to 15 layers of management on top of you.

job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: People are always helping you. Mobility is encouraged. To succeed in this business, you have to be aggressive. Make sure you come prepared.
cons: Like at any company, you can be unfortunate to have an incompetent manager. For the most part, you will need to manage the downside while imagining the upside, and always remember that there is a year end review.

pros: Free coffee and tea. Ability to telecommute depending on the manager.

People are insecure and a lot of infighting for projects. Strange how the CIO pressures us to reduce our spending, tells us there isn't enough money for better pay and bonuses, tells us our project funding is being cut, along with regular talk of headcount ramp-downs, but managers fly back and forth from NY to London to India. Also, plenty of senior managers hired from the CIO's previous company, who then hired their team members from the company, even though we went through a hiring freeze.

review_title: If you want to do ibanking, nowhere is great, but MS is better than most

- Not an ahole culture
- Groups aren't huge, less hierarchy than most banks
- Tons of recruiters / headhunters reach out to you
cons:
- It's banking after all so not thaaat much fun to be honest
- Pay isn't great given how much you're working
- that's about it

review_title: Challenging work, growth opportuntiies could be much better
pros:
Challenging work - fulfilling to see the impact of your work.
Work/Life balance was decent.  Work was generally decided for you.
There were not a lot of interruptions and meetings, allowing you to focus and deliver.
Co-workers were generally nice and capable.
cons:
Growth prospects were uncertain - management didn't seem to invest in individual growth.
Compensation was not correlated with performance.
Organization structure was very hierarchical, you rarely interacted with those higher than two levels above you.

pros: Ok place to be.  Good environment.  People respectful.  Always changing.  Generally there are opportunities to move up or around if you are able to navigate or elbow your way.
cons: As above, always changing.  Need to be tied to revenues closely if you seek high pay - which makes sense.  Otherwise don't expect a lot of big increases

job_title: Registered Client Service Associate in Greensboro, NC

Advisors would treat the CSA poorly and the manager would do nothing.

job_title: IBD Associate in Los Angeles, CA

No place is perfect but general consensus among current employees and former (again, below senior management) is that most places offer a better culture and stronger compensation than MS.

review_title: Excellent at headquarters, tougher in the field

review_title: Killer Perks, too big and protracted. No sense of team spirit.

review_title: One of the best companies on Wall Street to work for!

review_title: Great place to work, great training and great upside!

cons: Theres is not any work life balance with this job.  You come to work stress and leave stress. Managers are always in meetings and never on the floor. No opportunity to learn from Senior management because all of the managers are so new.  Rules are always changing and it is never consistent.

pros: Great learning opportunity, ability for internal ability, day to day interruptions with NY, UK, for Hungary it's a good salary
cons: No understanding of foreigners needs, poor level of couching in your direct role, poor level of career development (they do it, but it feels that not many managers understand the meaning of this process), external mobility to other offices is very difficult (very low percentage of people gets it)

pros:

- good benefits
- easy access to public transportation

job_title: Financial Analyst Intern in Bethesda, MD
pros: Good starting internship. The people there are very nice and willing to help. Overall a good starting internship. Would recommend for sophomores.
cons: The pay is pretty low for a financial industry internship. The work is also exclusively grunt work. There is also no incentive for working faster or more efficiently.

review_title: Operations is for those with little drive
pros: Work is at a minimum. operations areas are an easy paycheck, but people get too comfortable and do the minimum.  Its a comfortable job.
cons: Complete waste of time.  If you want to switch to any type of front office position good luck.  Half the skills you learn are a complete throw away.

review_title: Great meritocratic environment, but with significant churn
pros: If you find the right group and management, Morgan Stanley is a true meritocracy -- employees are appreciated and recognized for good work and ingenuity.
cons: Be prepared for change -- constant change.  Back office employees change managers, buildings, and organizations on a recurring basis.  As well, the industry is doing a "musical chairs" exercise right now, so departures and new hires are frequent.

review_title: Balanced work/life but not enough intellectual satisfaction
pros:
There are many pros:
Very smart colleagues, open doors, many forums to share knowledge, good people, good work/ life balance, good benefits,
cons: I personally felt there was a lack of intellectual satisfaction for me. Not much challenges to take and be proud of. Did not feel I was learning enough on the job

review_title: Great place to go, not start
pros: The best fixed income desk in the business. Syndicate is fantastic if you have the production and client base to get access to any new issues. You're in the center of the world.
cons: Terrible pay and benefits. No expense accounts. All the marketing, sales development, and lead sources are paid by the trainee. Unless you are on a team you get no marketing support. Training is almost non-existent. I had a great complex but unfortunately they were over worked and understaffed.

job_title: Due Diligence Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great People and Great Benefits. I learned a great deal of information and was able to take advantage of the excellent benefits!
cons: In certain departments there are few opportunities for advancement. Additionally they make no effort to offer employment mobility to other areas of the firm.

pros: I personally think it's a decent place to start off- despite the fact that the skills  and knowledge you accumulate aren't very pertinent to much else. I think as an intern, you learn more about the soft-skills which is important. I would not stay here and here and expect much of a career
cons:
-Seems like only horizontal progressions
-criteria for promotion/progression is vague and inconsistent. 
- Culture is paper thin, and constantly shifting and readjusting

review_title: I enjoy working at Morgan Stanley
pros:
- supportive and friendly teams and atmosphere
- interesting day-to-day tasks that support professional development
- exposure to other cultures and nationalities
- flexible management so long as you do a proper job
cons:
- limited development and promotion opportunities, no long-term career development opportunities as the place of business is located elsewhere
- bureaucracy and countless policies 
- sometimes too many meetings and other multinational activities take up your whole working day

pros: respectable company to work for, seems like some departments may be nice to work in.  they are open to letting you move within the company without your manager sand bagging you to keep you.
cons: on the service side of things you gain more and more responsibility and levels of expertise with no increase in pay.  cant say that i've ever seen a company consider a move into a management position as lateral before.

review_title: Spent 4 months interning with MSSB in Atlanta
pros: High standard;  steep learning curve and super nice people; always help you when you confront a problem or even run into trouble in your life. Learned a lot about basic finance knowledge through the internship.
cons: sometimes could be overly intensive; people's instruction could be vague and they expect you to figure it out yourself, which sometimes is basically impossible (for example, they would assume you already familiar with lots of jargon and concepts which can not be looked up online

pros: Great place to start and learn the business.  Paid training.
cons:
Once your business is established you are significantly better off leaving and going independent.  Payouts don't only jump from 40-45% to 90%+, but there is compensation that isn't credited to your grid that makes the pay closer to 3 to 4 times more, not just double.

All the resources you have at MS is available on the independent channel and more.  You have a harder time figuring out what to do than finding something at all.

review_title: Advisory center needs to understand direction and alignment
job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Jordan, UT
pros: Flexible work schedule, colleagues are good people.
cons: Leadership has no clue of the culture in south Jordan and they do not know what their plan is moving forward, too much shooting from the hip. Lack of communication between managers and advisors.

pros: Large company, stable, big balance sheet.  Big budget to reinvest in technology and product. Have the ability to provide a customer service and solutions that are first rate.
cons: Difficult to have a voice or provide feedback.  Information flows one way, down hill with zero interest in garnering any other perspective. Constantly have to lobby for pay, and justify your compensation.

pros: People in business are good, really good professionals. They might not be always friendly, but the level at which they operate is excellent. The learning curve is steep and you will have the chance to work with some of the best in banking and finance in general
cons: Hours can be very long, and colleagues not that nice. Compared to other banks there is no bound between colleagues and former colleagues and people, despite being proud of working for the company, don't have a bound to it

review_title: Strong company,  much vested interest with planning
pros: Dynamic company with benefits. Nice offices, and company has some well meaning principles, which if they were adhered to, would be good.
cons: Watch your back. Watch out for those who know how to play the game. Too many people get promoted for supporting their friends rather than adding value.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Tons of opportunities for career advancement and professional growth. Intelligent teams of people, some of the best, so you can easily find your niche and become an expert in the area of choice. The culture of giving back to communities/charities is another plus.
cons: Work/Life balance can be challenging. It is a big bank, so they are still traditional in some ways. While other companies have taken advantage of technology, working at MS still requires a lot of face-time and in many cases, long hours.

pros:
Supports in career development.
Great place to learn nitty gritty of work assigned to you.
cons: There are cons in every entity. Bias exists everywhere because this depends on the manager. in short, not everyone is the same. A corporation is not responsible as such but managers are. You will find few managers who exceptionally perform and help people under them to perform in similar manner and vice versa.  Personally have not met with negativity and have loved to work at Morgan Stanley.

job_title: Business Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Challenging work (a lot different than line operations), senior management exposure, true agile environment, collaborative coworkers and able to add value even as a junior employee
cons: A lot of politics and key stakeholders can be rude. Can feel micromanaged by stakeholders demanding transparency.  Seem to be interviewing non stop and have very low retention

review_title: PWM is stuck between a rock and a hard place.
pros: Vast array of resources. operational support via telephone is helpful.
cons: No real structure or training along with no operation support.  Lots of videos but those aren't super helpful.

review_title: Great company that offers support in growing business and training to be a great advisor.
job_title: Financial Advisor Associate in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Offers a lot of support and resources to excel in growing your business. Focused on being competitive with other financial services companies and consistently improving the CRM systems and ease of working with clients.
cons: Could provide more training for new hires. Difficult to ramp up commission and to be successful when not working with a Senior Partner or Team. Very independent oriented work-place culture.

job_title: Market Risk Associate in New York, NY
pros: some really nice people and good cafeteria.
cons: Not great for junior people. Working hours were exceptionally long (8-8 was more than normal, often longer) and compensation much lower than the median. Huge mismatch between the pay and the expectations. Lots of stress and high responsibility,  micromanagement, mandatory weekend work all the time despite really low comp. No free food or even drinks like coffee or tea in the office, had to pay for everything.

job_title: Technology Consulting Consultant in New York, NY
pros: fortune 500 company; looks good on resume, innovative environment, learn alot, good connections, money can be good
cons: layoffs, instability, long hours, too much change, corporate culture not that great especially with the younger crowds, people stick to themselves, not alot of social events going on, on my floor there was no break room except for a dorm size refrigerator and microwave, and a water cooler which didnt have any cups in it usually

review_title: Good days come when the economy is gloomy because clients tend to do nothing

review_title: Excellent financial firm to work for
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY

Offices in Manhattan are very nice (with some getting recent upgrades!), and technology is kept as up-to-date as possible.  Staff collaborates very well.

review_title: Financial advisors are on their own....

review_title: Redefining its business and revenue model...

The company is adapting to changing market and regulatory conditions, challenging the traditional business model. review_title: Don't expect to get a big raise or promotion
job_title: Registered Client Service Associate in New York, NY

cons: What they say about never getting a raise is true. Being outstanding and having perfect performance reviews doesn't make one bit of difference. It's also too big of a company to have any space for creating solutions. Red tape everywhere.

review_title: Low Morale, high bureaucracy, a lot of internal politics as people try to grab a smaller pie.
pros: Good reputation, great system for self learning. Still a lot of very smart people.
cons: Not much loyalty or culture as turnover has been very high in the last years. Pay is bad and too much politics to focus on your job.

review_title: Only interested in the bottom line
job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY

job_title: Trading Assistant in New York, NY

job_title: Financial Advisor in New York, NY

pros: I have a great opportunity to learn as from experienced professionals.  Very flexible with work and school.  Willing to help me out with recommendations and networking.

job_title: Financial Advisor/Private Banking Advisory Associate in New Orleans, LA

Learning lending did not help much when it came to meeting the goals required of a financial advisor.

pros: Work with smart people who want to learn and progress in their career. a great place to start. def. a place to consider

pros: Intelligent and interesting co-workers.  Many opportunities to learn. Great facilities and resources. Collegiate environment where most people are really open to share their knowledge.

pros: Fast paced, good people and great learning opportunity

review_title: Management up to regional level is terrible-essentially brokers turned managers.

pros: Great learning experience, especially if you're on a brokerage or analytical career track.  Very professional workforce.

review_title: Ideal for interns, not for professionals

review_title: good starting point for a carer but limited opportunities to grow past associate level

review_title: Great company but Stingy with Pay

review_title: Retired from MORGAN STANLEY SMITH BARNEY because the retirement was reducing under MORGAN STANLEY.
pros: Commission sales based on your efforts . You earn what you earn based on your work and your clients are your friends and partners in that work .
cons: Too much goes to pay New York salaries that do not help in the field with products that are not responsive to clients needs .

review_title: Morgan Stanley is a great place to work.
job_title: Risk Manager in New York, NY
pros: Of all the large banks I've worked at, Morgan Stanley has the best overall life/work balance. Each division is different, of course, but the Technology & Data organization was very supportive of my professional and personal needs.
cons: Huge place. There's bound to be a certain degree of anonymity, so you have to go out and make your own connections/network.

pros: Morgan Stanley is a very progressive company. They have a lot going for them and promote employee well being. Great place to work.

pros: Morgan Stanley is a great place to work at.  Over my 10+ I have worked at two different positions and learned tremendously from my colleagues.

pros: Great experience, work with some of the best on the Street, competitive compensation, opens a lot of doors for future employment
cons: Intense culture, expect to work long hours, "up or out" mentality means that if you don't keep advancing in the corporate hierarchy, your days are likely numbered and leads to some infighting

pros: Insightful to the services they offer and good practical experience of the role finance plays in running of a bank.  Lots of opportunities to shadow and high conversion rate following completion of interview.
cons: Too long - 13 weeks - so takes up whole summer. Others do a 6 week internship and still get same outcome from it.  Pay is very poor in comparison to London

pros: It was an open culture with lots of learning opportunities. Good place to grow with lots of smart people. huge learning curve with fundamental analysis

review_title: Great work culture but outdated test
pros:
1. You get to experience everything at a scale that only a few organizations can offer.
2. There are plenty of opportunities to groom your personality outside of projects and work

1. They have a lot of legacy systems and most of the IT work is to update the systems from old to new technology stack, which is kind of boring.
2. It's very management driven organization. Your opinions, ideas will be heard but don't think it makes much difference.

review_title: Highly respected company and for good reason...
pros: Supportive environment with opportunity to work alongside some very talented people. People really do care at this firm.  The firm operates with a no-blame culture. If something goes wrong, the first thing managers say is how do we fix it. Good benefits and great amenities in the London campus.
cons: Senior management is sometimes detached from the work that happens on the ground. I have often worked very long hours, with MDs not aware or recognise the hard work and dedication.

review_title: Good place to work for Short time
pros: No Micro Management, Lot of Opportunities to work on different kind of projects, Decent Salary, Can learn People Management Skills, Work from Home options available
cons:
1. Work Life Balance, imagine working from 12pm to 10pm that excludes travelling time
2. Don't think to stay in Company for longterm, as every 2 years firing of employees start. Currently every region is impacted except India.
3. Your perception by others is valued more than the work performed by you

review_title: Great place to work.  Will challenge and help you to go beyond your current abilities.

review_title: Great bank, but little work/life balance
pros: The compensation is great but is increasingly geared toward stock.  Ethical standards are high.  The people are great, a lot to learn from.  Very teamwork oriented.
cons: Work life balance leaves a lot to be desired - at the end of the day its an investment bank and the nature of the job.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Decent dase salary.  I enjoyed working with my colleagues very much.
cons: Underperformance is a big problem.  The company became a Frankensteins monster of a bank.  For a long time it couldn't decide which it wanted to be, either a retail oriented firm or the IB of old.

review_title: Surrounded and lead by very qualified individuals which makes you feel proud to be part to be part of the firm.

review_title: Review of Citi Smith Barney (prior to merger with Morgan Stanley)

review_title: Smart people, pleasant culture, not great pay
job_title: IT Associate in New York, NY
pros: Morgan Stanley is quite strong technically. I work in IT, and I'm quite impressed with the technical sophistication of the shop. The culture is very pleasant too. Not the cut-throat competitive atmosphere I feared when I first started working at the firm.
cons: I think they need to make an effort to be a bit more competitive salary-wise. Many talented people leave due to relatively low pay for Wall Street.

review_title: Used to be a great firm, but is slowly headed in the wrong direction
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY

pros:
It is hard to recommend working for this company, however:
Excellent education and learning plans. 
Easy to work from home (even with short notice)
Pay is good
Good place to stay for a short while just to learn how NOT to do programming/software development.
If you want to coast, then this is the place. If you just keep your head down and shut up in meetings you can linger there forever.
cons:
Indoctrination, they hire grads and interns with little or no experience and drill into them that this is a great place to be. After which it is impossible to carry a healthy self-critical conversation with them. The propaganda posters are the worst with their graphs of unlabelled axis touting how great the company is.

Institutionalized workforce, they want to mould you to be a "Morgan Stanley" employee. With as little transferable skills as possible. Build everything in house to keep people from acquiring real skills (they even went far enough attempt to build their own programming language). A lot of the younger crowd don't realise this until it is too late. Dull eyes.

Lack of talent, the bar is set so incredibly low that you almost have to dig for it. Technical skill of the average programmer is mediocre at best. But their boasting is through the roof, most suffer from a serious case of the Dunning–Kruger effect. Don't even start me on the strats, that sorry bunch of hacks.

Overall lack of motivation, no body cares about anything. All talk and no action. People have meetings about having meetings about other meetings and then they go home. Nothing gets done. And if by accident something is done, it is done in the absolutely the worst lacklustre way possible.

Political nightmare, nobody seems to be doing any work as they're all busy pointing fingers blaming everyone else, sorry I meant "escalating". People actively inject themselves into conversations that have nothing to do with them. Everybody is scrambling for their own little intern/grad/indian to "manage". Going to team/dept drinks is nothing short of a sickening brown-nosing session which most managers lap up (as most deliberately surround themselves with yes-people). 

Severely backwards when it comes to technology and software. They're still running on WindowsXP in 2012. Nothing gets upgraded until it is already out-dated, which is a favourite complaint on the in-house mailing list.

Actively hostile environment to software developers. Development environment crash constantly (i.e. Visual Studio and Eclipse) due to over-the-top restrictive access controls and antiquated OSs. C++ devs have it the best but only because they use Textpad or something even more primitive.

Computers are slow, software is slow, people are slow, EVERYTHING IS SLOW!

review_title: Horrible Pay and Conditions in Wealth Management Capital Markets
job_title: Wealth Management Capital Markets in Purchase, NY
pros: Great gym. Free parking onsite.
cons:
This review specifically applies to wealth management trading floor based primarily in Purchase that covers top Financial Advisors' UHNW, middle market and HNW Clients. The division falsely advertises  itself as Capital Markets, that is NOT to be confused with the venerable Global Capital Markets desk in the city that brings deals to the market for major companies. 

Firstly, the horrible compensation ranges say it all:

After ones first three years, compensation  (both base and 'bonus') is far below street avg even within UHNW/how bucket:
- Analyst ( yrs 1-3): $95k-$120k
- Associate ( yrs 3-6): $110k- $160k
- VP ( yrs 6-10): $110-$170k --> you are stuck now and doing exact same work as A2
ED (yrs 10- infinity): $150-$250k 

In the past four months alone, the unit has lost 12 of its stronger performing analysts, associates and younger vps. It even lost its HR Rep in charge of "retaining talent." One would think management would be inquisitive as to this brain drain, especially when they trumpet the wealth management's staff support's "intellectual capital" as a point of strength in helping the firms top individual Clients. But they have not nor do they seem to care. They recruit finance and Econ majors from schools like Harvard, Brown, Georgetown, BC, Nova etc, train them up over a year period, only to lose many by year three. THE ENTIRE ANALYST CLASS OF 2008 IS GONE; all left to greener pastures. 

Over the last four years, there has been 4 different heads of this division. That's right- MDs in charge of managing a 300 person division that produces a half billion in revenue per year just can't seem to stick around. This volatility at the top trickles down to the next rung of management (EDs and newer MDs) where a culture of solo performance, selfishness, complete lack of communication and mendacity permeates the environment. 

Some  examples:
 

- Multiple colleagues have told me, and I've heard it myself, that their manager told them that their performance review nor rating does NOT determine ones compensation. When pressed on what actually determines compensation, no manager has ever explained it. If for example you are a trader at the associate or vp level  and produced $15MM in PnL for the year, you could very well get a 'bonus' of $20-30k pretax, and a low base; very uncompetitive for a 11 hr/day job with a 1 hr commute each way. This has occurred multiple of times to multiple ppl; don't think you'd be an exception. Regardless, no manager has ever explained the discrepancy between performance and pay. One can only infer it is because the division's management is of extremely poor quality and does not advocate senior execs on the divisions value add. 

- stagnate compensation between analyst-vp. Many second year analysts get paid as much if not more than first-third year vice presidents. One third year associate recently left to  lesser competitor and was offered twice their MSWM capital markets total compensation. 

- three star associates who made VP in the last four months left to competitors after they found out their promotion came with a DROP in year on year compensation. They wete doubled at other firms. What kind of management promotes its up and coming officers only to then lower their year on year pay? Bad managers. 

- There is an institutional desk in the city at Broadway and 42nd- where management should encourage relationships and communication to open up, there actually is a policy that says sales staff in Purchase cannot communicate with their colleagues in the city about any market/ job related issue.

- On top of a traders' PnL not being linked to anything comp related, neither are the sales force's sales commission. A sales person may do proactive trades that generate $10mm in gross credits over a year, but the managers do not attribute that work at the end of the year to that persons' efforts. Instead liken it to something that would have happened anyway. Well, what's the point of having a sales force then. 
 

If you don't believe those numbers just do a check on glassdoor but select "Purchase" as location, not nyc. If you decide to join this desk despite this warning, realize you will. E joining a glorified help desk

pros:
Glasgow office staff try very hard to keep the office fun.
Nice gym and nice canteen.
cons:
Where to start.......?
Hardware is obsolete. PC was under spec'd and 4 years old when I joined. Servers were 10+ years old. Software developers need decent spec'd PC's. Time is money and when your PC can take 30+ seconds to display Outlook due to only having 2Gb of memory (2010!!) and using 4Gb of swap... well....
Software quality is non-existent
Only manual testing performed by un-trained over worked team who know little about software they are testing.
No automated testing to speak of. No unit tests.
1 manual test cycle per release. Any issues found are brushed over. Most code is not tested.
Monthly releases done between 11pm and 7am Friday night to Saturday morning. Release dates can change and in 20 months working there I had two holidays cancelled due to changing dates without recompense. (lost hotels, concert tickets). When I complained I got told "perhaps investment banking is not for you"
Staff totally over stretched. Very bright people are producing terrible software due to lack of continual personal development and absolutely no peer review system.
Many of the engineers don't understand source control. Code is regularly copied around.
Most engineers don't understand md5sum's, diff, patch etc.
No code reviews whatsoever. Literally anything could be put into the code base. Think Superman III and Richard Pryor's half penny scam etc. Simply unacceptable in a place working with so much money.
Lots of paperwork filling and box ticking - Understandable if the processes we're doing the paperwork for work. Pointless if they don't.
Regularly people don't know what they are doing or the area they are working in and so lie / make things up so as not to look bad in front of management. Results in countless hours / days wasted each month with people having to double check things as you simply can't trust what anyone outwith your immediate team says.
Interview process was dreadful. Many applicants had no proper competency testing and their applications were fast tracked because of their previous employment history and not their actual skills.

review_title: The Training Program is a Con
job_title: Financial Advisor Associate in Dallas, TX
pros: MSSB has one of the best brands in the retail brokerage business
cons: Look, becoming a financial advisor a la Morgan Stanley, Merrill, et al is at best a daunting task.  However, ask yourself, how do these firms profit from month after month bringing in FA trainees knowing full good and well that only about 1 in 10 make it five years and only about 2 in 10 even make it to 18 months?  The answer:  Trainees don't cost much.  Getting new clients, even for established FA's is getting harder and harder.  The "financial advisor" profession is way past saturated.  Secondly, the biggest trend in the profession is for FA's at the brokerage firms to either go purely independent as fee-based RIA's, or at least go to a much lower cost/higher payout platforms such as LPL.  Sooooo, what about our trainees?  Well, even the worst trainees are going to bring in one or two or so good accounts before they self-select out due to not making much money or the firm fires them for not hitting sales goals.  And, who gets those good accounts when our trainee leaves MSSB?  You got it, the established brokers get them, NOT struggling new FA's.  Put another way, the training programs are nothing more than client acquisition programs for the established FAs.  Giving these guys the accounts is one of the ways the traditional brokerage firms try to keep them from bolting to greener pastures.  In the meantime, our trainees are back on the street trying to find real jobs.  The only trainees who ever make it are those who have either family members or a big rolodex of close acquaintances who will give them substantial money very soon.  If you are not in that category, remember:  You are expected to bring in a few good accounts reasonably soon and then leave the firm.  In short, the best outcome for the brokerage firms is for trainees to become big producers.  But, that's not the plan.  If it were, do you think the failure rate would be anything approaching 90%?  Really?  No, the second best, and by far the most likely outcome, is for you to bring in a few good accounts and then leave the firm as soon as possible.  It's a very cynical model and is just one example of why the traditional retail brokerage firms are continuing to lose market share to just about everybody else.  Even retail prospects/clients are beginning to ask questions like "Why am I paying so much in fees and commissions?"  "What the heck is my performance and how does it compare to an appropriate benchmark?"  Those are not questions the Morgan Stanleys of the world want to hear.  But, for job seekers, just understand, it's a rigged game.  Morgan Stanley, Merrill, UBS, et al have a perverse, short-term model that is designed for you to fail.  Although they are encouraging FAs to go to fee-based models, it's simply in their DNA to view all prospects/clients as nothing more than a source of revenues.  In fact, all you really have to know is that the only thing... the only thing.... that they grade all FA's on is how much money they make off of every client. so long as they don't break any regulations.

job_title: Graduate Operations Analyst in Glasgow, Scotland
pros: Good, smart, driven young people (but will never be given the opportunity to do any meaningful work)
cons:
Compensation in Glasgow is horrific. You get an inflationary bonus every year if you're lucky (£500, yes £500, barely beating inflation). You will never make money in Glasgow.

Gynocentric culture.

Big focus on women and minorities, no equality for the straight white male.

No vision in Operations - Senior managers think Blockchain is 'overhyped' (Against all other data, only because it doesn't suit their interests).

Too many people doing jobs that can be offshored or automated (Assume management dont want this flagged to their overlords to maintain their current pay checks, less people = less pay for them).

No room for growth. At all. Once you reach VP level they will keep you for a few years then boot you out to hire another VP for less pay. Seen it happen at least 7 times.

Management genuinely have a chip on their shoulder towards younger staff (I assume its because they know they have their full life ahead of them whilst they have spent the 90's and 2000's working in Operations which wont exist in a few years)

Management are generally not very knowledgable.

Its common for people to make misongynistic, homophobic and racial jokes (100% serious) even management, in the office and group WhatsApp conversations. HR generally dont want to rock the boat and intervene. 

Beachballs, Stressballs and other stuff gets thrown around the office like a nursery. Really unprofessional. Even seen nerf guns. The VP brought it in, absolute child. 

This is probably a Pro but not from their perspective, people move to other departments by bypassing HR and networking with senior group members in other departments (IBD, S&T, Research, Strat). Operations team up with HR to tell everyone this is not possible, but it happens all the time, and makes an absolute mockery of any influence they have in the organisation (Which is literally 0)
